thread.title: Why this Bideford man doesn’t want you to be ashamed of your period

author: Nicole Travers-Wakeford
title: Why this Bideford man doesn’t want you to be ashamed of your period
text:
Why this Bideford man doesn’t want you to be ashamed of your period Trained facilitators including Ben help girls explore how periods can affect them both physically and emotionally Share Ben Paddon will be touring with the Betty Bus Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
“Talking to children about periods might strike someone as quite daunting, but this job has taught me that breaking these taboos aren’t as difficult as you might think”. 
This is what one man from Bideford feels about his new job which involves talking to children about menstruation. 
Ben Paddon’s new job is to tour the country with the Betty Bus to talk to children about periods and help youngsters feel more comfortable learning about the female cycle. 
Children can take part in interactive activities and sessions with trained facilitators, like Ben who help girls explore how periods can affect them both physically and emotionally. Ben Paddon is from Bideford in North Devon 
The youngsters are also encouraged to ask questions that they may not feel comfortable raising in the classroom. 
Ben is a trained actor with a first class honours degree from the Arts University Bournemouth. 
He said: “Sometimes children might not want to out rightly talk about periods, so we use a system that gets them thinking about it in a different way. I think the betty bus is successful because to me, it’s a new take on teaching. The Betty Bus Miracle twins born three months too early - but just look at them now 
“We get them out of a conventional classroom setting and we get them involved in fun activities. 
“There are so many fantastic moments that come with a project like this and seeing the change in a student from the beginning of a session to the end is so rewarding. 
“They sometimes feel disinterested to begin with and then leave with so many questions -Their thirst for knowledge is amazing.” The youngsters are also encouraged to ask questions that they may not feel comfortable raising in the classroom Read More 
The bright yellow Betty Bus is a free educational tool aimed at eight to 12-year-olds at schools across the country. 
Trained facilitators help girls to explore how periods can affect them. 
The bus will park on school grounds and can take up to ten groups of 20 year 5, 6 or 7 girls on a rolling programme across the day. The bright yellow Betty Bus Read More Political chiefs assure worried Devon farmer that post-Brexit future is bright 
The information on the Betty Bus website states: “The workshops will involve a selection of experiential activities and a team challenge. 
“Each workshop lasts approximately 50 minutes. The boy’s workshops will focus on their understanding and attitude towards this perfectly natural time of month.” Children can take part in interactive activities and sessions with trained facilitators, like Ben who help girls explore how periods can affect them both physically and emotionally Read More Coca-Cola has revealed its famous Christmas truck tour dates - and it's coming to Devon 
The bettyforschools.co.uk website also has tips and advice for parents as well as youngsters. Parents can log on to the website to gather advice on how to help your daughter deal with heavy periods, bra shopping and acne. 
The website also gives parents of boys some advice including signs of puberty and how to diffuse moody swings in “five easy steps”. Like us on Facebook
